<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of make_blocking:
```c
static void
make_blocking (MHD_socket fd)
{
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (fd, F_GETFL);
  if (-1 == flags)
    abort ();
  if ((flags & ~O_NONBLOCK) != flags)
    if (-1 == fcntl (fd, F_SETFL, flags & ~O_NONBLOCK))
      abort ();
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  unsigned long flags = 0;

  if (0 != ioctlsocket (fd, (int) FIONBIO, &flags))
    abort ();
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function make_blocking:
#define MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS 1
...
typedef int MHD_socket
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code. The fragments present are plain, standard-C constructs: a static function definition, preprocessor conditional compilation (#if defined / #elif / #endif), typedef use (MHD_socket as int), local variable declarations, standard casts ((int) FIONBIO), calls to platform/library functions (fcntl, ioctlsocket, abort), integer/bitwise operations, and macro symbols (F_GETFL, O_NONBLOCK, F_SETFL, FIONBIO). None of these are compiler-specific language extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions, __extension__ or other compiler-only keywords/constructs. The use of POSIX vs WinSock API identifiers (fcntl/FIONBIO/ioctlsocket) reflects platform-specific APIs, not language extensions; they are conditional on macros and therefore outside the scope of MISRA C Rule 1.2 (which targets compiler language extensions). Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for Rule 1.2.
